Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was double-checking the data tables for my research report. The journal’s submission portal was open on my laptop, the countdown clock glaring at me: two hours left. I was so close to finishing, but then I saw it was Jamie calling. Her voice was frantic—she was already halfway to the airport and thought she’d left her passport at home. “Can you check and, if it’s here, bring it to me? Please?” she pleaded. I glanced at the clock again, feeling my chest tighten. As a friend, I knew she was counting on me; missing her flight would be a disaster. But as a scientist, I had a responsibility to submit my findings on time, with every detail checked and every dataset uploaded. The pressure from both sides was crushing. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, Jamie’s anxious voice echoing in my mind, and felt completely torn—pulled between the urgency of a friend in need and the demands of my professional integrity.
